questions.question_text_1: Consider a server that has an Intel i5 processor, 64 GB RAM, 1 TB Hard disk with 3 Gbps network connection. If a client accesses a web page, it requires 1.5 MB. questions.question_text_1: The speed vs. throughput characteristics of a typical HDD is shown in the figure below. If this HDD is to be used as a replacement of an SSD whose read/write speed is 450 MB/s. At what speed (in RPM) should the disk of HDD rotate with to deliver the same performance as that of the SSD?

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the exam, followed by **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships. --- ## **Core Topics & Concepts Summary** ### **1. Web Development Fundamentals** #### **URL Structure** - **Components**: - **Protocol**: `https://` (e.g., HTTP, HTTPS, FTP). - **Domain Name**: `www.example.com` (or IP address). - **Path/Directory**: `/home` (optional). - **Query Parameters**: `?user=Mad1&key=madcs2003` (key-value pairs after `?`). - **Fragment**: `#section1` (optional, for in-page navigation). - **Example**: ```plaintext https://www.mywebsite.com/home?user=Mad1&key=madcs2003 ``` - Protocol: `https` - Domain: `www.mywebsite.com` - Path: `/home` - Query: `user=Mad1&key=madcs2003` #### **HTTP Methods** - **GET**: Retrieve data (idempotent). - **POST**: Submit data (non-idempotent). - **PUT**: Update existing data (idempotent). - **DELETE**: Remove data (idempotent). - **PATCH**: Partial update. #### **HTTP Status Codes** | Code | Meaning | |------|-----------------------------| | 200 | OK | | 201 | Created | | 400 | Bad Request | | 401 | Unauthorized | | 404 | Not Found | | 405 | Method Not Allowed | | 500 | Internal Server Error | --- ### **2. Flask Framework** #### **Key Concepts** - **Routing**: Map URLs to functions using `@app.route`. ```python @app.route('/home') def home(): return "Welcome!" ``` - **Templates (Jinja2)**: - Render dynamic HTML using `render_template`. - **Control Structures**: ```jinja2 {% if condition %} ... {% endif %} {% for item in list %} ... {% endfor %} ``` - **Filters**: ```jinja2 {{ item|length }} {# Length of item #} {{ item|upper }} {# Convert to uppercase #} ``` - **Request Handling**: - Access query parameters: `request.args.get('key')`. - Access form data: `request.form['key']`. - Access JSON data: `request.get_json()`. - **Redirects & Errors**: ```python from flask import redirect, url_for, abort return redirect(url_for('login')) abort(404) # Return 404 error ``` - **Flask-RESTful**: - Build REST APIs with `Resource`, `Api`, and `reqparse`. - Example: ```python from flask_restful import Resource, Api, reqparse parser = reqparse.RequestParser() parser.add_argument('name', required=True) ``` #### **Flask-SQLAlchemy** - **Model Definition**: ```python class User(db.Model): id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True) name = db.Column(db.String(50)) ``` - **Queries**: ```python User.query.filter_by(name="Alice").first() # Single result User.query.filter(User.age > 25).all() # Multiple results User.query.get(1) # Get by primary key ``` - **Relationships**: - One-to-Many: ```python class Parent(db.Model): children = db.relationship("Child", backref="parent") ``` - Many-to-Many: Requires an association table. - **CRUD Operations**: ```python db.session.add(user) # Create db.session.commit() # Save user.name = "Bob" # Update db.session.delete(user) # Delete ``` #### **Flask Test Client** - Simulate requests: ```python with app.test_request_context(): print(url_for('home')) # Output: / ``` --- ### **3. HTML & CSS** #### **HTML Structure** ```html Page Title

Hello

Paragraph

``` #### **CSS Selectors** | Selector | Example | Description | |----------------|------------------|--------------------------------------| | Element | `p` | All `

` elements. | | ID | `#header` | Element with `id="header"`. | | Class | `.text` | Elements with `class="text"`. | | Attribute | `[href]` | Elements with `href` attribute. | | Pseudo-class | `a:hover` | `` on hover. | #### **Box Model** - **Properties**: `margin`, `border`, `padding`, `content`. - **Example**: ```css div { margin: 10px; border: 2px solid black; padding: 20px; width: 200px; } ``` #### **CSS Specificity** 1. Inline styles (`style="..."`). 2. IDs (`#header`). 3. Classes (`.text`), attributes, pseudo-classes. 4. Elements (`p`, `div`). --- ### **4. Database & SQL** #### **SQLite with Flask-SQLAlchemy** - **Create Table**: ```python class User(db.Model): id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True) name = db.Column(db.String(50)) ``` - **Indexing**: ```python db.Index('idx_name', User.name) # Create index ``` - **Filtering**: ```python User.query.filter(User.age > 25).all() User.query.filter_by(name="Alice").first() ``` #### **SQL Queries** - **SELECT**: ```sql SELECT * FROM users WHERE age > 25; ``` - **INSERT**: ```sql INSERT INTO users (name, age) VALUES ('Alice', 30); ``` - **UPDATE**: ```sql UPDATE users SET age = 31 WHERE name = 'Alice'; ``` - **DELETE**: ```sql DELETE FROM users WHERE id = 1; ``` #### **Joins** - **Inner Join**: ```sql SELECT * FROM users INNER JOIN orders ON users.id = orders.user_id; ``` - **Left Join**: ```sql SELECT * FROM users LEFT JOIN orders ON users.id = orders.user_id; ``` --- ### **5. Testing with Pytest** #### **Fixtures** - Reusable setup/teardown: ```python @pytest.fixture def sample_data(): return ["apple", "banana"] ``` - **Test Example**: ```python def test_length(sample_data): assert len(sample_data) == 2 ``` - **Fixture Dependencies**: ```python @pytest.fixture def processed_data(sample_data): return [item.upper() for item in sample_data] ``` #### **Assertions** - Check equality: `assert result == expected`. - Check exceptions: ```python with pytest.raises(ValueError): risky_operation() ``` --- ### **6. Performance & Scalability** #### **Bandwidth Calculation** - **Formula**: \[ \text{Bandwidth (Gbps)} = \frac{\text{Total Data (GB)} \times 8}{\text{Time (seconds)}} \] - **Example**: - 10,000 requests × 150 KB = 1.5 GB. - Time = 1 second → Bandwidth = \(1.5 \times 8 = 12\) Gbps. #### **Time Complexity** - **O(n log n)**: Sorting algorithms (e.g., Merge Sort). - If 500 entries take 100s, 1200 entries take: \[ \frac{1200 \log 1200}{500 \log 500} \times 100 \approx 273 \text{ seconds} \] #### **Throughput** - **Formula**: \[ \text{Requests per Second} = \frac{\text{Bandwidth (Gbps)} \times 10^9}{\text{Request Size (bits)}} \] - **Example**: - 3 Gbps bandwidth, 1.5 MB request size: \[ \frac{3 \times 10^9}{1.5 \times 8 \times 10^6} \approx 250 \text{ requests/sec} \] --- ### **7. RESTful APIs** #### **Design Principles** - **Stateless**: No client context stored on the server. - **Resource-Based**: URLs represent resources (e.g., `/users`). - **HTTP Methods**: - **GET**: Retrieve resource. - **POST**: Create resource. - **PUT**: Replace resource. - **DELETE**: Remove resource. #### **Flask-RESTful Example** ```python from flask_restful import Resource, Api class UserResource(Resource): def get(self, user_id): return {"user_id": user_id} api.add_resource(UserResource, '/users/') ``` #### **Request/Response** - **Request Body (JSON)**: ```json { "name": "Alice", "age": 30 } ``` - **Response (JSON)**: ```json { "status": "success", "data": {"name": "Alice", "age": 30} } ``` --- ### **8. Jinja2 Templating** #### **Key Features** - **Variables**: `{{ variable }}`. - **Loops**: ```jinja2 {% for item in items %} {{ item }} {% endfor %} ``` - **Conditionals**: ```jinja2 {% if user.authenticated %} Welcome, {{ user.name }}! {% endif %} ``` - **Macros** (reusable components): ```jinja2 {% macro render_user(user) %}

{{ user.name }}

{% endmacro %} ``` - **Filters**: ```jinja2 {{ name|upper }} {# Convert to uppercase #} {{ list|length }} {# Length of list #} ``` --- ### **9. System Design** #### **Hard Disk vs. SSD** | Metric | HDD (7200 RPM) | SSD | |--------------|----------------|--------------| | Read/Write | ~100 MB/s | ~500 MB/s | | Latency | High | Low | | RPM | 3600–15000 | N/A | #### **Scalability** - **Vertical Scaling**: Upgrade server hardware (CPU, RAM). - **Horizontal Scaling**: Add more servers (load balancing). --- ## **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs** ### **1. Web Development Ecosystem** ```mermaid graph TD A[Web Development] --> B[Frontend] A --> C[Backend] A --> D[Database] B --> B1[HTML] B --> B2[CSS] B --> B3[JavaScript] C --> C1[Flask] C --> C2[Django] C --> C3[Node.js] D --> D1[SQLite] D --> D2[PostgreSQL] D --> D3[MongoDB] ``` ### **2. Flask Workflow** ```mermaid graph LR A[Client Request] --> B[Flask Router] B --> C{Route Match?} C -->|Yes| D[View Function] C -->|No| E[404 Error] D --> F[Template Rendering] D --> G[JSON Response] F --> H[HTML Response] ``` ### **3. HTTP Methods & Status Codes** ```mermaid graph TD A[HTTP Methods] --> B[GET] A --> C[POST] A --> D[PUT] A --> E[DELETE] B --> B1[Retrieve Data] C --> C1[Create Data] D --> D1[Update Data] E --> E1[Delete Data] F[Status Codes] --> F1[200 OK] F --> F2[201 Created] F --> F3[400 Bad Request] F --> F4[404 Not Found] ``` ### **4. Database Operations with SQLAlchemy** ```mermaid graph TD A[SQLAlchemy] --> B[Model Definition] A --> C[CRUD Operations] A --> D[Relationships] B --> B1[db.Model] B --> B2[db.Column] C --> C1[db.session.add] C --> C2[db.session.commit] C --> C3[db.session.delete] D --> D1[One-to-Many] D --> D2[Many-to-Many] ``` ### **5. Testing with Pytest** ```mermaid graph TD A[Pytest] --> B[Fixtures] A --> C[Assertions] A --> D[Parametrization] B --> B1[@pytest.fixture] B --> B2[Reusable Setup] C --> C1[assert result == expected] C --> C2[Exception Testing] D --> D1[@pytest.mark.parametrize] ``` ### **6. Performance Metrics** ```mermaid graph TD A[Performance] --> B[Bandwidth] A --> C[Throughput] A --> D[Latency] B --> B1[Gbps] B --> B2[Data Size] C --> C1[Requests/Second] C --> C2[Concurrent Users] D --> D1[Response Time] D --> D2[Network Delay] ``` --- This summary covers **all critical topics** from the question paper, with **equations** (where applicable) and **Mermaid graphs** to visualize relationships. Focus on: 1. **Flask** (routing, templates, SQLAlchemy). 2. **HTML/CSS** (selectors, box model). 3. **HTTP** (methods, status codes). 4. **Testing** (pytest fixtures). 5. **Performance** (bandwidth, time complexity).
